citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The ear medication, Tri-Otic ointment, being used for a female Sheltie (MC# 004520301) expired 02/2020. Expired
medications do not ensure that the medications are effective at treating disease or illness and the health of the animal
may suffer. Each dealer shall use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. The
facility must ensure all medications are not expired.
The facility had not identified one male Westie (MC#004365823) in poor dental health. The upper right and left canine
teeth and cheek teeth were 50% or more covered in a dark brown organic material. The one left upper incisor, left upper
canine tooth and right upper canine tooth had a buildup of grey organic material along the gum line. The gums above the
upper canine and cheek teeth were heavily thickened and hard to the touch. Poor dental health could cause pain and
discomfort to the dog, as well as lead to further health issues. The licensee must use appropriate methods to prevent,
control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries in the regulated animals and ensure each animal receives adequate
veterinary care at all times. The licensee must have this dog evaluated by a licensed veterinarian to access their health to
develop an effective treatment plan. These medical records must be available for APHIS inspection.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The licensee has not consulted her attending veterinarian regarding the conditions and medical treatments of two dogs.
Female Bichon (MC#839317011) is receiving an iodine treatment once per day for a toe pad injury and Female Sheltie
(MC#004520301) is receiving two ear medications (Tri-Otic once a day and Zymox Plus every 5 days) for an ear condition
and head tilt. The inspector called the attending veterinarian to confirm appropriateness of the treatments being given.
The attending veterinarian said the medications seemed appropriate but without seeing the animal or a photo of the issue
could not be sure on treatment. They stated the licensee should have contacted them at the time of the injury on the
Bichon and after a week of no improvement for the ear condition of the Sheltie to discuss treatment options.
. A mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of
animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian so the animals can receive adequate
veterinary care. The licensee must communicate with the attending veterinarian to have the dog's conditions evaluated.
To be corrected by: 16-October-2023

The licensee is not keeping medical records of problems identified and treatments being given for the following dogs:
Female Bichon (MC#839317011) iodine treatment applied once per day for a toe pad injury
Female Sheltie (MC#004520301) two ear medications being given (Tri-Otic once a day and Zymox Plus every 5 days) for
an ear condition and head tilt
Shih Tzu puppy (ID number 23031) Neo-Poly-Dex eye drops twice a day for an eye condition
Without proper documentation, it is difficult to determine the efficacy of a treatment plan and ensure the animals are
receiving adequate veterinary care. A proper medical record includes the date the problem was found, a description of the
problem, the name and frequency and amount of medications used, examination findings, test results, plans for treatment
and care, and treatment procedures performed must be recorded and a copy kept for review for inspection by APHIS
officials. Correct by ensuring all records of any treatments for problems identified in the dogs are recorded and maintained
at all times.
To be corrected by: 16-October-2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

3.13(b)(2)

Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee is not keeping medical records of problems identified and treatments being given for the following dogs: 
Female Bichon (MC#839317011) iodine treatment applied once per day for a toe pad injury 
Female Sheltie (MC#004520301) two ear medications being given (Tri-Otic once a day and Zymox Plus every 5 days) for 
an ear condition and head tilt 
Shih Tzu puppy (ID number 23031) Neo-Poly-Dex eye drops twice a day for an eye condition 
Without proper documentation, it is difficult to determine the efficacy of a treatment plan and ensure the animals are 
receiving adequate veterinary care. A proper medical record includes the date the problem was found, a description of the 
problem, the name and frequency and amount of medications used, examination findings, test results, plans for treatment

at all times.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
